statement:
The [*Levi problem*]{} is the problem of characterizing domains of
holomorphy by a local condition on the boundary that does not involve
holomorphic functions themselves. This condition turned out to be
pseudoconvexity.

An open set $G \subset {\mathbb{C}}^n$ is a domain of holomorphy if and
only if $G$ is pseudoconvex.

The forward direction (domain of holomorphy implies pseudoconvexity) is
not hard to prove and was known for a long time. The opposite direction
is really what’s called the solution to the Levi problem.

[9]{} Steven G. Krantz. [**]{}, AMS Chelsea Publishing, Providence,
Rhode Island, 1992.
